channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: At Globalfest, Music Speaks Many Languages
item.description: Globalfest 2014 was a 12-act world-music showcase that included dance music, gospel, African beats and many other genres.
item.media:credit: Brian Harkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fanfare Ciocarlia, a Serbian brass band, epitomized the variety onstage Sunday at Globalfest.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Doctor Is Sentenced in a Case of Baby Trafficking
item.description: Zhang Shuxia, an obstetrician in Shaanxi Province, received the death sentence but with two years’ reprieve for stealing seven babies and selling them.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: U.S. Journalist Is Barred
item.description: David Satter, an American journalist and the author of books on Russia and the Soviet Union, said he had been barred from the country by the Russian security services.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Pope With the Humble Touch Is Firm in Reshaping the Vatican
item.description: Francis has worked to dismantle the old career paths in the Vatican and has appointed moderates to top posts.
item.dc:creator: By JASON HOROWITZ and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeted cardinals on Dec. 21 at a hall in the Apostolic Palace of the Vatican, where he addressed church officials.

item.title: Enemies of Mexican Drug Gangs Pose a Security Challenge
item.description: The armed men calling themselves self-defense forces may include members of the gangs themselves, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Men belonging to the Self-Defense Council of Michoacán rode on a sandbag-filled truck in the town of Nueva Italia, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: DealBook: Japan’s Suntory Buys Jim Beam for $13.6 Billion
item.description: The move means such longtime American brands as Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons will be owned by a Japanese giant.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED and DAVID GELLES
item.media:description: In addition to Maker's Mark, Suntory is acquiring brands like Canadian Club whisky and Courvoisier cognac.

item.title: Japan’s Leader Pledges Aid on Africa Tour
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe finished a visit to Africa during which he offered aid and development projects potentially worth billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn of Ethiopia at a news conference in Addis Ababa on Monday.

item.title: Obama Fights a Push to Add Iran Sanctions
item.description: President Obama’s struggle to prevent Senate Democrats from backing strict new sanctions that could upend his diplomatic efforts is casting a long shadow over talks with Iran.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: President Obama fears that strict new sanctions gaining support in the Senate could upend his nuclear negotiations with Iran.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rare Waterlily Is Stolen
item.description: A minuscule, nearly extinct waterlily has been stolen from London’s Royal Botanic Gardens, officials said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Andrew Mcrobb/Royal Botanical Gardens Kew, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Nymphaea thermarum, considered the world’s smallest waterlily.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Deadly Bombings Erupt in Baghdad
item.description: At least 29 people were killed as car bombs struck several Shiite neighborhoods in northern Baghdad on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: Rivals Agree to a Truce
item.description: Northern rebels and Salafist Islamists agreed to a cease-fire after weeks of fighting, the chairman of a Yemeni presidential committee said Monday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: German Envoys Are Attacked
item.description: Two German diplomats survived a shooting on their car while on a visit to eastern Saudi Arabia on Monday, the state news agency SPA reported.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Nigerian President Signs Ban on Same-Sex Relationships
item.description: The ban signed into law by President Goodluck Jonathan threatens violators with 14-year prison terms, and it is considered the most significant setback to gay rights in Africa.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The signing by President Goodluck Jonathan was not publicized apparently to avoid offense to other countries where such relationships are permitted.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Presidential Warning Against Betrayal
item.description: Nearly two weeks after a Rwandan spymaster turned dissident was found dead in South Africa, President Paul Kagame said those who had betrayed Rwanda could expect to face consequences.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Village Blast Kills 14
item.description: An explosion on Monday afternoon in a village near Kaili in the southwestern province of Guizhou killed 14 people and injured seven, state media news reported.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Bowed and Remorseful, Former Red Guard Recalls Teacher’s Death
item.description: A daughter of the Communist Party elite has offered public penance for her part in one of the most notorious killings of the Cultural Revolution.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Song Binbin, third from left, before a bust of Bian Zhongyun, the leader of a Beijing high school who was killed in 1966.

item.title: Television Review: PBS ‘Frontline’ Looks Inside a Notoriously Closed Country
item.description: PBS’s “Frontline” goes inside the North Korea of Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE HALE
item.media:description: This PBS documentary, on Tuesday night, shows work inside the country by clandestine photographers.

item.title: Nigerian Leader Signs Law Banning Gay Associations
item.description: Nigeria’s president has signed a law that bans same-sex marriage and criminalizes homosexual associations, societies and meetings, with penalties of up to 14 years in jail.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Hard-Liners in Iran Offer Mild Praise for Interim Nuclear Agreement
item.description: Conservatives cautiously welcomed the completion of an interim agreement that would provide Tehran with some relief from Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Tent City in Central African Republic Swells as Violence Grips Capital
item.description: More than 100,000 people have fled the threat of violence at home despite the poor living conditions at the chaotic camp by the airport on the edge of Bangui.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: In less than a month, more than 100,000 people moved to a tent city by the airport in Bangui, Central African Republic, because of the threat of violence.

item.title: By Degrees: The Flood Next Time
item.description: The numbers are unmistakable, scientists say. Global sea levels are rising, while land along the East Coast is sinking. Just ask Norfolk, Va.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Stephen Gill, an oceanographer for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, at the Battery tide gauge in Manhattan. Tides have been measured there since the 1850s.

item.title: Ronaldo Dethrones Messi as World Player of Year
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo, who scored 66 goals in 56 games last year, did not win a team trophy, but he did lead his national team to a place in the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Ronaldo, left, with Pele, right, broke down in tears on Monday night after being named FIFA’s world player of the year.

item.title: Israel Bids Farewell to Sharon, a ‘Complex Man’
item.description: The military and political elite, and foreign dignitaries including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., were among those who gathered to honor former Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who died two days ago.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: The funeral on Monday afternoon for Ariel Sharon, the former Israeli prime minister, drew citizens as well as dignitaries to his family ranch in the Negev desert.

item.title: DealBook: 5 Chinese I.P.O.’s Shelved After Regulator Stiffens Rules
item.description: The China Securities Regulatory Commission announced that it would tighten restrictions on public offerings, shortly after the first new share sales since 2012 had been approved.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: The ChiNext market in Shenzhen, a secondary board mostly for start-up companies, in 2009.

item.title: Syrians May Allow the Delivery of Some Aid
item.description: Diplomats have been discussing the delivery of humanitarian aid to some besieged areas, to set a positive tone for peace talks beginning Jan. 22.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Pablo Martinez Monsivais
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, talked about Syria on Monday in Paris.
